list_definition.mean_english: mạng che mặt; khăn trùm đầu
list_definition.definition: a piece of thin cloth worn over the face or head to hide, cover, or protect it

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Some women wear veils for religious reasons, to prevent strangers from seeing their faces
a veil of mist over the mountains
The clouds veiled the sky in grey.

list_ex_of_english: This is quite a different approach to justice than postulating a veil of ignorance.
The veil of prudery and so-called good taste must be torn aside from this subject.
Why do these values translate only to bias-neutralizing, aversion to uncertainty, the veil of ignorance, and equality?
If anything, the experiment indicates their heightened risk-aversion in conditions of uncertainty, underscoring appeal to risk-aversion behind the veil.
Second, the reactionary tone of the contributions is only thinly veiled (indeed at some points, not at all).
Behind the veil of ignorance, would not we all agree to limited, humane preemptive strikes for the safety of all?
The veil of ignorance is a useful theoretical tool because bias toward oneself can potentially subvert understanding of social justice.
Teasing and withholding, veils are the stuff of suspense.
